hints.content: Start by understanding what a perfect number is. A perfect number is equal to the sum of its positive divisors, excluding itself. For example, for the number 28, the divisors are 1, 2, 4, 7, and 14.
Consider how to find the divisors of a number. You can iterate from 1 to n/2 (inclusive) and check if each number divides n evenly. If it does, it's a divisor.
Remember, you should not include the number itself in the sum of its divisors. Make sure to only add divisors that are less than n.
Think about optimizing the divisor search. Instead of checking all the way to n/2, you can check up to the square root of n. For each divisor found, you can also consider its complementary divisor.
When you find a divisor, you might want to add both the divisor and its complement (n/divisor) to the sum, but be careful not to add n itself.
Consider edge cases. What happens if n is 1? Remember that 1 has no positive divisors other than itself, so it cannot be a perfect number.
Make sure to initialize a variable to hold the sum of the divisors. You will be updating this variable as you find divisors.
After calculating the sum of the divisors, compare it to n. If they are equal, return true; otherwise, return false.
As a final check, ensure your implementation can handle the upper limit of the input constraints, which is 10^8. Test your solution with both small and large numbers.
Your function should return a boolean value. Make sure to return 'true' if n is a perfect number, and 'false' otherwise. Consider edge cases and performance.

questionNotes: A perfect number must be a positive integer.
Do not include the number itself in the sum of its divisors.
